title: How to tell if you're going blind or will be blind soon - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, the first answer from Robert Hayes makes a lot of sense to me. See an Ophthalmologist and ask him or her if you have a potentially blinding disorder. Of course in most cases, if they are honest with you, the Ophthalmologist will tell you they don't know. If you are already blind, it's a little easier to tell you if you are likely to stay blind or regain some vision, but if you are not blind it's quite hard to predict if or when you will go blind. If you don't want to go to have your eyes checked by a professional, but would like to try to figure this out for yourself, you could decide what disease you think you have (preferably a blinding one in order to answer your own question), and then look up how frequently people go blind with that condition. There are lists of diseases in world blindness studies that could give you a starting point. If you decide to pick a disease that would otherwise be treatable, but you still don't want to see an Ophthalmologist, you can speed up the estimated time to blindness considerably by avoiding treatment. A good sign that you MAY actually be going blind, would be a rapid decrease in vision in one or both eyes. Again, by not seeking care, I would say that you would increase your odds of actually succeeding in going blind. There you have it. If you think you may be going blind, or are losing vision, go see an Ophthalmologist or optometrist. Or don't. And “see”* what happens. Maybe you will eventually go blind. Probably not. But don't expect a good answer on Quora to a vague medical question like that. Instead, you will get answers like this one. *(just a little ophthalmology joke there)

It would be obvious as its occurring but at times it happens so slow that you may not realize it till it's to late. My injuries occurred in late 1977 and I really didn't notice much change till couple months ago. The bag in my left eye ruptured by but the leak was very small nut through the years the tear got larger so I'm losing more fluid. I have a total blind spot about center left and now have to use very dark sunglass plus and I patch when in sunlight. Like many things you gradually get use to this things but they are super annoying. I'm really hoping that the surgery at least slows it down or causes a complete stop. And if not I'll learn to live with it, what other choice do i have. I'm extremely grateful for the job my doctors at the VA have done for me and others.

You would be more likely to getting notified of decreasing vision and possible blindness if you retain regular doctor visits to check your eyesight and any possible pressures on the nerves. However there isn’t a real solid away unless they know exactly what is wrong with you and you always have the possibility of having an accident your eyesight. Speaking from personal experience last minute 116

Hard to answer since “going blind” is not a medical condition per se, but symptomatic of something else. As such, the first signs of going blind — that is, lacking the ability to see — may be gradual or sudden, partial or complete, localized to one eye or to both, etc. and is based on the underlying cause. Unless you are drinking, of course . . .

If you are totally blind, as is my husband, you cannot see. He never opens his right eye, which does not have an optic nerve. He opens his left eye, which does not have a retina, only when really excited about something. He sees by touch and hearing. He recently got an Orcam (orcam.com), which is a camera that will read to him and do facial recognition. He had a hard time learning to use it because “look at…” means turning his ear towards the thing. Imagine wearing a blindfold that lets no light in. That is how his world has been for over 50 years.

It’s pretty easy. Someone says “Look at that!” You say “Look at what?” They point and say “That! Right there!” You say “What are you talking about?” They look at you sarcastically and say “You don’t see the girraffe?” You say “What girraffe?” Pretty good bet you’re going blind OR your friend is a jacka**. Cheers.

This depends on what their condition is, such as cataracts; the person themselves will notice that it seems to be foggy all the time. The biggest sign that someone might be loosing their vision is when they start to have a hard time seeing things, being able to read without assistance, bumping into objects frequently, reaction time slowing significantly.

In addition to the other answer, even people who are legally blind can sometimes see something. The image may be just shadows or a blurry outline. Combining experience, acute senses of hearing and smell may sometimes give the impression that the blind person seems to see when they really can’t. Offer assistance if it seems appropriate. Most blind people are pretty independent and like to do things on their own.

Blindness can be caused by: *Eye infections *Being hit in the eye with a strong force (punch or object falling from height) *Corrosive substances in the eyes (acid or any other harmful chemicals) *STD's, for example: if you somehow manage to get genital worts in the eye it can cause blindness. (Touching your eyes after masturbating or shooting at your eyes with your sperm) Those are just a few examples, hope this helps.
